{"step_by_step_thinking": "Based on the patient's history and examination findings, the most likely diagnosis is a stress fracture of the third metatarsal. Stress fractures are common overuse injuries that occur due to repetitive trauma. The patient's symptoms of diffuse forefoot pain, worsening with activity and at rest, along with tenderness over the third metatarsal, are consistent with a stress fracture. X-ray findings of cortical density loss and callus formation further support this diagnosis. The next step in management would be to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the injury. This can be done with a technetium bone scan, which is a sensitive imaging modality for detecting stress fractures. Rest and acetaminophen may provide symptomatic relief, but further evaluation is needed to guide appropriate management. Ultrasonography is not the most appropriate next step as it may not provide sufficient detail to evaluate the extent of the stress fracture. Internal fixation is not indicated at this point as it is typically reserved for cases of displaced or unstable fractures.", "answer_choice": "C"}
